metadata.title: Title: 2D/2D Nano-Hybrids of -MnO2 on Reduced Graphene Oxide for Catalytic Ozonation and Coupling Peroxymonosulfate Activation

sections.text:
Two-dimensional reduced graphene oxide (2D rGO) was employed as both a shape-directing medium and support to fabricate 2D γ-MnO2/2D rGOnano-hybrids (MnO2/rGO) via a facile hydrothermal route. For the first time, the 2D/2D hybrid materials were used for catalytic ozonation of 4-nitrophenol. The catalytic efficiency of MnO2/rGO was much higher than either MnO2 or rGO only, andrGO was suggested to play the role for promoting electron transfers. Quenching tests using tert-butanol, p-benzoquinone, and sodium azidesuggested
that the major radicals responsible for 4-nitrophenol degradation and mineralization are·O2¯ and 1O2, but not ·OH.Reusability tests demonstrated a high stability of the materials in catalytic ozonation with minor Mn leaching below 0.5 ppm. Degradation mechanism, reaction kinetics, reusability and a synergistic effect between catalytic ozonation and coupling peroxymonosulfate (PMS) activation were also discussed.
Keywords: Graphene,γ-MnO2, 4-nitrophenol, catalytic ozonation, peroxymonosulfate

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Aqueous organic pollutants containing phenol and its derivatives discharged from refinery processes and households demonstrate detrimental effects to both the environment and human beings. As one of the common industrial effluents, 4-nitrophenol is widely used as a raw material and has been discharged to waters from productionprocesses of pharmaceuticals, pesticides and dyes[1]. Due to its high toxicity even at a very low concentration as well as the recalcitrance to self-degradation in the natural environment, 4-nitrophenol was listed as one of the 129 priority pollutants by the United States Environmental Protection Agency[2]. Therefore, it is highly imperative to develop effective methods and strategies for mineralizing 4-nitrophenol in industrial wastewater and contaminated groundwater.
In the past years, extensive research interests have focused on the advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) for degradation of organic pollutants due to their non-selectivity and highly efficient mineralization[3, 4].Among AOPs, hydroxyl radicals with ahigh oxidative potential (E0=2.7 V) have been confirmed to be effective and non-selective for organic pollutant oxidation[3, 5]. Utilizing these hydroxyl radicals, Fenton/Fenton-like reactions have become one of the most prevalent AOPs because of the high efficiency and cost-effectiveness[6]. However, the requirement of low pH, metal leaching and large amount of sludge production became the bottleneck of their broader application[7].Traditional ozonation process has been extensively used for oxidation of unsaturated aromatic and aliphatic compounds. However, it was hindered by the low reaction rate with saturated organic compounds[8].Recently, catalytic ozonation process has proven to be an efficient strategy for aqueous organic pollutants removal[9-11].By the contribution of homogeneous/heterogeneous catalysts, ozone
could produce larger amount of reactive species that can be utilized for persistent organic pollutant degradation[10].Xing et al.[12]reported the effect of the type and numbers of basic sites of activated carbon on the reaction pathways in catalytic ozonationof oxalic acid. Cao et al. [8] modified a commercial activated carbon using nitration and amination methods and applied the modified materials for catalytic ozonation of oxalic acid.
Recently, manganese-based materials have been widely employed as electrodes, catalysts and supercapacitors due to their excellent physical and chemical properties[13-15].When used as catalysts, the variation of the oxidation state (Mn4+/Mn2+) in manganese based materials involving a single electron transfer enables them to have superior potential as active sites for catalytic reactions.[14] Moreover, the abundant existence in soil and low toxicity to the environment facilitate the wide applicationsof manganese based materials in AOPs[5, 14,16- 18].On the other hand, materials in two dimensional (2D) structure have drawn massive research attention, not only for the outstanding physical and chemical phenomena that occur when transportation of heat and charge is confined to a plane, but also for the promising coupling effects when these 2D materials are composited to other materials [19, 20]. Graphene/reduced graphene oxide (rGO) is one of the fascinating 2D materials with preeminent chemical stability, electrical conductivity and surface to volume ratio[21, 22].With the aid of these properties, graphene/rGO has been intensively employed as a catalyst support for various metal oxides such as TiO2, Fe3O4 and ZnO[23-25].And recently, some MnOx/graphene nanohybrids were fabricated and applied for energy storage and environmental remediation[26-29]. Hu et al. prepared MnO2/graphene composite by using GO and KMnO4 as precursors for catalytic ozonation of gaseous toluene and identified the role of graphene in the catalytic reaction[29].Li et al. investigated the catalytic activity of 3D sea-urchin like α-MnO2/graphene composites in removal of bisphenol-A[30].However, to the best of our knowledge, noMnOx/GO or MnOx/rGO hybrids in discernable 2D structure have beenpreparedfor heterogeneous catalytic ozonation of aqueous pollutants.
Previously, using exfoliated rGO served as both a support material and a shape-directing platform to produce 2D γ-MnO2 requires addition of surfactants in synthesis[31].In this study,
2D MnO2/2D rGO structure (MnO2/rGO) was successfully fabricated via a facile low temperature hydrothermal method. The prepared MnO2/rGO showed excellent activity for catalytic ozonation and mineralizationof 4-nitrophenol. The reaction kinetics and reusability of the catalysts were studied. Classical quenching tests were employed to investigate the dominant reactive species generated for 4-nitrophenol degradation. Furthermore, experimental results showed that MnO2/rGOproduceda synergistic effect between catalytic ozonationandperoxymonosulfate (PMS)activation for oxidation.

sections.heading: 2.1. Chemicalsand sample synthesis
sections.text: Graphite oxide (GO) was prepared by a modified Hummers’ method[32].In order to obtain rGO, 1g GO was transferred into a crucible and then heated in a muffle furnace at 350 oC for 1h. MnO2/rGO samples were synthesized by a hydrothermal method (detailed procedure shown in the Supporting Information).

sections.heading: 2.2. Characterization of materials
sections.text: The physicochemical properties of various synthesized samples were characterized by several techniques, including X-ray diffraction (XRD), scanning electron microscopy (SEM),transmission electron microscopy (TEM), N2 adsorption/desorption,thermogravimetric-differential thermal analysis (TG-DTA), and X-ray photoelectron microscopy (XPS). Detailed procedures are shown in the Supporting Information.

sections.heading: 2.3. Catalytic ozonationprocess.
sections.text:
Catalytic ozonation of 4-nitrophenol was carried out in a 1 L semi-batch reactor with constant stirring at 300 rpm. Unless specifically stated, the concentration of 4-nitrophenol was 50 ppm. The whole device was submerged into a water bath ata constant temperature of 25 oC. Ozone was generated by an AnserosOzomat GM ozone generatorfrom high purity oxygen (99.5%). The detail process is presented in the Supporting Information.
3. Results and discussion

sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of the materials
sections.text:
X-ray diffraction wasfirstly employed to investigate the crystalline structure of the materials. Fig.1 displays the XRD patterns of rGO, MnO2/rGO-A and MnO2/rGO-B. For rGO, a sharp peak at 25.2o was observed, while no diffraction peak at 11.0o was discerned, indicating that afterthe thermal treatment, GO was fully reduced to rGO[33].For both MnO2/rGO-A and MnO2/rGO-B, the diffraction peaks found at 2θ of 22.1, 36.9, 42.2, 56.2 and 68.4owere well in agreement withthose of ramsdelliteγ-MnO2 (JCPDS: 44-0142; I4/m(87)) with 1 × 2 tunnel structure[34, 35].The peaks could be indexed to (101), (210), (211), (212) and (610), respectively. It was noteworthy that the rGOdiffraction peak at 25.2ofor MnO2/rGO-A was not as strong as that of MnO2/rGO-B due to half rGO loading as compared to MnO2/rGO-B.
Morphology and structure of the samples were evaluated by SEM images (Figs. 2(A and B)). It can be observed that, for the both samples, MnO2 and rGO were chemically combined with each other without distinct boundaries to form a 2D pan-cake-like hybrid nanostructure. MnO2 was constructed by interlinking and edge sharing of the basic [MnO6]8-octahedra in
different configurations[13]. And structurally,γ-MnO2 consists of a hexagonal close-packed anionic lattice in which [MnO6]8-octahedra share four edges to form a 1 × 2 tunnel structure[35].Previous studies reported that, without the addition of a surfactant, it was difficult for γ-MnO2 to form 2D flat structure with the presence of a cation only like K+ due to its 1 × 2 tunnel structure[31].By introducing the well-dispersed 2D rGO, the MnO2 nuclei could deposit on the rGOnanosheets and gradually developed during the hydrothermal process.The 2D/2Dhybrid structure was further revealed by TEM images (Fig. 2(C and D)). As seen, γ-MnO2particles grew and anchored tightly on the surface of the rGOnanosheets to form an intimate combination, which could induce fast electron transportation between the rGOnanosheetsand γ-MnO2 particles to provide the outstanding chemical performance[36].From the SEM and TEM images, it could be concluded that rGOnanosheets provided a green 2D skeleton for the growth of MnO2. However, due to the confinedrGO skeleton, MnO2/rGO-Aand MnO2/rGO-B (Fig. 2(A) and (B)) displayed a quite similar particle size with 100 nm in width, 200 nm in length, and around 10 nm in thickness. Energy dispersivespectra (EDS, Fig. S1 (A and B)) clearly show the difference in weight/atomic composition of these two samples.In terms of the atomic percentage of C element, MnO2/rGO-B obtained more than twice of the C element in MnO2/rGO-A (46.2% vs. 22.3%), suggesting the higher composition of rGO skeleton in MnO2/rGO-B, in accordance with the difference in synthesis procedures. Moreover, EDS confirmed the formation of MnO2/rGO hybrids, where only Mn, C and O elements on the rGO sheets can be detected with Al and Si peaks generated from SEM stubs.
(A) (B)
Figure 2(A)SEM image for MnO2/rGO-A, (B) SEM image for MnO2/rGO-B, (C) TEM image for MnO2/rGO-A,and (D) TEM image for MnO2/rGO-B.
BET specific surface area and pore size distribution of the samples were examined by N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms (Fig. 3). Both samples demonstrateda type IV isotherm with a type H3 hysteresis loop revealing a mesoporous structure [26].As seen in Fig. 3 (B), MnO2/rGO-Bshowed a broad hysteresis loop ranging from 0.30 to 0.99 of the relative pressure, P/P0. While the hysteresis loop of MnO2/rGO-A(Fig.3 (A))was narrower, starting at 0.40 and ending at 0.99, suggesting a less porous structure and thus a smaller surface area and pore volume. Shown in Table 1, MnO2/rGO-B presents a higher BET specific surface area (35.2 vs. 28.9 m2/g) and larger pore volume (0.30 vs. 0.21 cm3/g) than MnO2/rGO-A, well constant with their hysteresis loop features. Considering the similar morphology of the two samples, the higher BET surface area and pore volume of MnO2/rGO-B could be attributed to the higher content of rGO skeleton involved in the sample. For pore size distribution, MnO2/rGO-A displayed a pore size distribution with threemodes concentrated at 3.4, 6.6 and 17.7 nm, respectively. While MnO2/rGO-B demonstrated a multi-modal pore size distribution, centered at 3.4, 4.8, 6.5 and 17.4 nm, respectively. Previous studies suggested that the pores centered at around 5 nm could be assigned to the contribution of MnO2 while the larger pore size is mainly resulted from rGO[5, 16,37].

Figure 3Nitrogen sorption isotherms and pore size distribution for (A) MnO2/rGO-A and (B) MnO2/rGO-B. Inset: Pore size distribution.
TGA-DSC was employed to investigate the chemical composition and thermal stability of MnO2/rGO under airflow, and the results are shown in Fig. 4. For both samples, four weight
loss processes could be observed from their TGA profiles. The initial weight loss occurring at temperature below 150oC could be ascribed to the removal of the physically adsorbed water molecules [38]. Since the evaporation of adsorbed water molecules was a mild process, the DSC curves fluctuated without a characteristic peak within that temperature range. Then the gradual weight loss happening from 150to 300oC could be attributed to the destruction of the oxygen-containing functional groups on the surface of rGO[39].The first characteristic DSC peak occurring at 400oC could be assigned to the decomposition of the carbon skeleton of rGOnanosheets[28]. While the second peak at 550oC contributing 8% of the total weight loss for both of the samples was resulted from the transformation of MnO2 to Mn3O4 by losing of oxygen from MnO2 lattice[17]. Comparing the TGA/DCS curves of MnO2/rGO-A and MnO2/rGO-B, it could be found that the DSC peak intensity of MnO2/rGO-B at 400oC was much stronger than that of MnO2/rGO-A. Moreover, from 300to500oC, weight losses resulted from decomposition of rGO for MnO2/rGO-B and MnO2/rGO-A were 20% and 10%, respectively, validatingthe rGO content determined in synthesis and shown in the EDS results. Furthermore, according to the TGA profiles, weight ratios of MnO2 for MnO2/rGO-A and MnO2/rGO-B were calculated to be 91.6% and 82.3%, respectively.

X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was employed to further evaluate the chemical bonding states for MnO2/rGO-B(Fig.5). Strong Mn 2p, O 1s and C 1s peaks were identified within the survey region (Fig. 5(A)). For spectrum of Mn 2p region (Fig. 5(B)), two characteristic peaks centering at 641.6 and 653.5 eV were observed, representing Mn 2p3/2 and Mn 2p1/2, respectively. And the spin energy separation of 11.9 eV was well in agreement with the reported spectrum of MnO2[40]. O 1s region could be fitted into three components. Peaks concentrated at 530, 531.5 and 533.7 eV could be ascribed to Mn-O-Mn, Mn-O-H and C-O/C=O, respectively [31, 40]. For C 1s XPS spectrum of the hybrid structure, peak located at 284.6 eV was attributed to C-C/C=C in the aromatic rings, while the peak located at 288.6 eV was assigned to O-C=O groups attached on the rGO surface [41].These XPS results were well in accordance with the XRD studies.

sections.heading: 3.2. Catalytic ozonation of 4-nitrophenol
sections.text:
Catalytic activities of the samples were examined by catalytic ozonationfor degradation of 4- nitrophenol (Fig. 6(A)). In order to provide a benchmark for catalytic performance of MnO2/rGO, control experiments were carried out to show self-adsorption,ozonation only, and catalytic ozonation using equal mole of rGO for 4-nitrophenol removal. For adsorption, insignificant amount of 4-nitrophenol was removed on both MnO2/rGOcatalysts within 1 h, suggesting that self-adsorption could induce little influence on 4-nitrophenol removal. For 4- nitrophenol decomposition using ozonation only, 4-nitrophenol was completely degraded in 60 min, revealing the oxidation capability of ozone itself. However, for TOC removal (Fig. 6 (B)), ozone itself could only attain less than 20% of mineralization of organic contents within 60 min.

Figure 6Catalytic ozonation with various catalysts and the corresponding TOC removal Reaction conditions: [4-nitrophenol]0 = 50 mg/L, Catalyst loading = 0.1 g/L, Ozone flow rate: 100 mL/min, Ozone concentration: 50 mg/L, and Temperature: 25 oC.
Catalytic ozonationof 4-nitrophenol using equal molerGOas that in MnO2/rGO-B was also carried out as a control experiment. As seen, both 4-nitrophenol degradation and TOCremoval curveswere almost the same as those from ozonation only, revealing that rGO at an equal molar amount of the MnO2/rGO-B could hardly generate active species for oxidation of organic contents. For catalytic ozonation, 4-nitrophenol removal using commercial MnO2 as a catalyst was also carried out. Although 100% 4-nitrophenol degradation was achieved,the same as that of ozonation, TOC removal was improved from 16% to around 50%.This indicated the good capability of the commercial MnO2 for organic
decomposition. For catalytic ozonation using MnO2/rGO catalysts, both the catalysts demonstrated higher4-nitrophenol degradation and TOC removal than the commercial MnO2. Complete 4-nitrophenol degradation was achieved within 30 min for the two catalysts, obtaining a remarkable improvement compared to that of the commercial MnO2. Furthermore, TOC removal rateswere elevated from 50% to 84% and 79% for MnO2/rGO-B and MnO2/rGO-A, respectively. The vast enhancement in catalytic performance soundly suggests that the as-synthesized 2D MnO2/rGO catalysts could effectively activate ozone to produce active species for both degradation and mineralization of 4-nitrophenol.
Previously, researches have widely applied MnO2in catalytic ozonation for organic pollutant removal due to their high catalytic activities[31, 42,43]. Dong et al. prepared α-, β- and γMnO2 via a uniform hydrothermal method using MnCl2 and KMnO4 at different molar ratios[42].Using phenol as the target pollutant, α-MnO2 demonstrated the highest catalytic ozonation activity and 60% of 300 ppm phenol was decomposed within 90 min when catalyst loading was at 1g/L. It was found that catalytic activity of α-MnO2is attributed to its active surface oxygen. While for β- and γ-MnO2, their catalytic activities were resulted from lattice oxygen. Shape-controlled α-MnO2 nanotube was also employed for catalytic ozonation for phenol degradation[42].In the experiments, 300 ppm of phenol was fully degraded in 60 min at 1.0 g/L of catalyst dosage. Considering that 4-nitrophenol is more difficult to degrade than phenol and that the catalyst loading in this study was far less than that used in the previous researches (0.1g/L vs. 1.0 g/L), it could be concluded that the 2D MnO2/rGO hybrid showed higher catalytic activity than traditional metal-only (MnO2 based) catalytic ozonation processes.

Figure 7Kinetic study of catalytic ozonation.
To investigate the reaction kinetics, a first order kinetic model[44]was applied to determine the reaction rate constant. Displayed in Fig. 7, the catalytic ozonation using MnO2/rGO and ozone onlywere well fitted by the first order kinetic model with high regression coefficients. And the reaction rate constants were thereby calculated to be 0.123, 0.104 and 0.039 min-1 for catalytic ozonation with MnO2/rGO-B, MnO2/rGO-A and commercial MnO2, respectively (Table 1). As seen, MnO2/rGO-B possessed the highest rate constant, indicating the fastest reaction rate for 4-nitrophenol decomposition. Compared with MnO2/rGO-A, the higher reaction rate of MnO2/rGO-B might be ascribed to the greater amount of active sites brought by the larger BET specific area. Moreover, both MnO2/rGO catalysts showed much higher reaction rates than that of commercial MnO2, which is well in accordance with the trends of 4-nitrophenol degradation curves.
In this study, the as-synthesized MnO2/rGO 2D/2D nanohybrids demonstrated excellent catalytic activity for removal of 4-nitrophenol in the simulated wastewater. However, in the real industrial wastewater, uncertain factors such as high salinity, presence of other organic compounds, and variations of solution pH might strongly influence the catalytic process. Lv
et al. revealed that the presence of 5mM of phosphate ions in the reaction solution will tremendously decrease the catalytic ozonation efficiency in 2,4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid removal[45].Another research revealed that catalytic ozonation efficiency could be enhanced by the presence of small amountofhumic substances (<1 mg/L as DOC), however, high amount ofhumic substances would bring in negative effects [46].
In order to investigate the effect of reaction conditions on catalytic activity, further experiments were carried outon MnO2/rGO-B. Fig. S2 illustrates the catalytic ozonation efficiencies and the corresponding TOC removal rates at varying initial 4-nitrophenol concentrations. As seen, a general trend can be observed that both 4-nitrophenol degradation efficiency and TOC removal rate would decrease with the increase of the initial 4-nitrophenol concentration. When 4-nitrophenol concentration was increased to 100 ppm, the time for complete degradation was prolonged to more than 60 min, and the TOC removal rate decreased from 80% to 40%.When 4-nitrophenol concentration was further increased to 150 ppm, only 60% of 4-nitrophenol could be decomposed within 60 min with the TOC removal rate of 15%. The significant decrease in catalytic efficiency by increasing the initial concentration of the pollutant suggests that the amount of reactive species generated during the catalytic ozonation process was too low for degradation of the pollutant at high concentration.
Fig. S3 presents the effect of ozone loading on catalytic efficiency. When ozone loading was decreased to 30 mL/min, 95% of 4-nitrophenol was degraded within 60 min and the TOC mineralization was 30%, which also experienced a remarkable decrease due to lack of ozone source to produce reactive species for organic degradation.

Figure 84-Nitrophenoldegradation and the corresponding TOC removal on MnO2/rGO-B for successive reusability tests. Reaction conditions: [4-nitrophenol]0 = 50 mg/L, Catalyst loading = 0.1 g/L, Ozone flow rate: 100 mL/min,Ozone concentration: 50 mg/L, Temperature: 25 oC.
The catalytic stability and the recyclability of MnO2/rGO-B were evaluated by a successive reusability test in which the catalyst was regenerated by simple water washing for three times (Fig. 8). The catalytic activity of 4-nitrophenol decomposition showed a decrease in the second run and complete 4-nitrophenol degradation was obtained within 60 min while the TOC removal dropped from 80% to 70%. In the third run, the catalyst displayed a similar efficiency as the second run, revealing the high catalytic stability and recyclability of MnO2/rGO-B. In the third run, 100% degradation of 4-nitrophenol was still achieved within 60 min. However, the TOC mineralization was slightly decreased to around 65%. The reaction solutionswere collected after each run and catalyst leaching was determined by inductively coupled plasma (ICP, Optima 5300DV, Perkin Elmer). It was found that Mn ions in the reaction solutions were less than 0.5 ppm, indicating that negligible loss of catalytic activity occurred due to Mn ion leaching. Moreover, the low ion leaching also suggests that contribution of homogeneous catalysis to the whole reaction was insignificant. The decrease of the catalytic activity for the second run might be ascribed to the adsorption of reaction intermediates on the surface of the catalyst. And the similar reaction rates for the second and
the third runs suggest that these reaction intermediates adsorbed on the catalyst surface cannot be removed by simple water washing. However, recent studies revealed that these attached intermediates could be partially or completely removed by sonication or heat treatment[17, 37]. Moreover, it was supposed that the composition change, especially the chemical state change of Mn, might lead to the catalyst deactivation.
It was known that free radicals such as ·O2¯, O-, 1O2 and ·OH were generated in the catalytic ozonation process, and that the dominant species (·O2-, ·OH or 1O2) in catalytic ozonation for organic pollutant degradation would vary depending on the catalyst[9, 47]. In order to investigate the reactive species responsible for 4-nitrophenol degradation in this catalytic ozonation using MnO2/rGO-B as a catalyst, classical quenching tests using tert-butanol (tBA), p-benzoquinone (p-BQ) and sodium azide (NaN3) as quenching agents were carried out. t-BA is a prevalent quenching agent for hydroxyl radicals with the reaction rate of 3.8×108- 7.6×108 M-1s-1, however, t-BA reacts rather slow with ozone at the reaction rate 3 ×10-5 M-1s1[48]. For quenching ·O2-, p-BQ is widely used as the scavenger[49]. The singlet O2was inhibited by NaN3, which is also an effective probe for hydroxyl radicals since their reaction ratesare close to each other (2×109 M-1s-1vs. 1×109 M-1s-1)[49, 50]. By addition of these quenching agents into the reaction solution, the dominant reactive species for 4-nitrophenol degradation could be differentiated.

Figure 9 Radical competition tests for MnO2/rGO-B for catalytic ozonation process. Reaction conditions: [4-nitrophenol]0 = 50 mg/L, Catalyst loading = 0.1 g/L, Ozone flow rate: 100 mL/min, Ozone concentration: 50 mg/L, Temperature: 25 oC, t-BA=12 mM, pBQ=12 mM, NaN3=12 mM.
The quenching tests are revealed in Fig. 9in the form of reaction rate constant (k). When 12 mMt-BA was added, less than 5% decrease in reaction rate constant was observed, suggesting that ·OH was not the major reactive species responsible for 4-nitrophenol degradation. On the contrast, when 12 mM p-BQ was added, the reaction rate dramatically decreased from 0.123to 0.014 min-1. The remarkable decrease in the reaction rate indicates that ·O2- could dominate the catalytic ozonation process.The addition of 12 mM of sodium azide provided the similar result and the reaction rate decreased to 0.016 min-1. Since hydroxyl radical was not effective for 4-nitrophenol decomposition, proven by the quenching test using t-BA, 1O2 was then identified to be one of the reactive species for organic decomposition. A quenching test employing both p-BQ and NaN3 was also conducted for the further confirmation. It was found that the reaction rate further decreased to 0.007 min-1, suggesting that most of the reactive species were successively quenched. Therefore, it has been validated that both ·O2and 1O2 were the dominant reactive species in this catalytic ozonation system using
MnO2/rGO as a catalyst.
Previous studies reported that single electron transfer involved in transition of Mn4+ to Mn3+ is responsible for catalytic reactions on Mn based catalysts[14, 17, 18, 42].In order to examine the chemical state change of Mn in catalytic ozonation system, XPS spectra ofMn 2p region from the fresh and used catalystswereinvestigated. Shown in Fig. 10, the XPS spectra of Mn 2p region were well consistent with reported results, in which Mn(IV), Mn(III) and a satellite vibration shake were observed[51, 52].The peak at around 641.7 eV could be assigned to Mn(III), and the peak at 642.2 and 642.7 eV was ascribed to Mn(IV). As seen, after the catalytic ozonation reaction, the relative composition of Mn(IV) increased from 28.9% to 37.2%, while Mn(III) composition decreased from 30.6% to 14.6%. The transformation fromMn(III) to Mn(IV) indicates that,under the strong oxidation environment ofozonation, some of the Mn(III) have been partially oxidized to Mn(IV) by experiencing electron transfer. As discussed above, this composition change might also bring out the slight deactivation of the catalyst. Therefore, it was confirmed that the redox reactions between Mn(III) and Mn(IV) induced by electron transfer took place during the catalytic ozonation process.The electron transfers occurring at the MnO2 surface serve as the active sites for catalytic reaction[42].
It is noteworthy that Mn(III)/Mn(IV) transformation ratio was much higher than those reported in the literature[42], revealing that,due to tight bonding with rGO, the speed of the electron transportcan be immensely acceleratedfrom a higher conductivity and thus the catalytic activity is improved. A few studies have applied MnO2/rGO or MnO2/graphene nanocomposites for catalytic reaction and acknowledged the role of rGO in accelerating the electron transport[1, 31].Hu et al. synthesized MnO2/graphene hybrids through a hydrothermal method for catalytic ozonation of gaseous toluene[31]. They found that, when MnO2 loading was 65 wt%, toluene removal rate reached the peak. In the process, the high catalytic activity could be from the tight connection between MnO2 and graphene to ensure the fast electron transfer. Moreover, the graphene provided a platform for adsorption of the toluene molecules.Very recently, 3D reduced graphene oxide modified sea urchin-like αMnO2 was prepared by Li et al. [1] using a simple hydrothermal method, and showed an excellent activity for catalytic ozonation for BPA degradation.The high catalytic activity of as-synthesized nanocomposites could be attributed to the large amount of active sites brought by the high surface area of the 3D morphology of α-MnO2. Furthermore, by tight bonding with rGO, the electron transfer within the catalyst had been promoted.

sections.heading: 3.3. Synergistic effect of catalytic ozonation with PMS
sections.text:
Control experiments were first carried to set a benchmark for evaluating 4-nitrophenol degradation with a synergistic effect of catalytic ozonation/PMS reaction. As seen (Fig. 11(A)), it was difficult for PMS itself to generate active species for 4-nitrophenol degradation. Mn/rGO catalysts were proven to be highly effective in activing PMS for phenol decomposition[27, 53]. However, when the degradation target was changed to 4-nitrophenol which was more recalcitrant to degradation and PMS dosage was decreased to 0.5 g/L, only 5% of 50 ppm of 4-nitrophenol was removed.

Figure 11 4-Nitrophenol removal with MnO2/rGO-B and its synergistic effect with PMS (A); the corresponding TOC removal (B). Reaction conditions: 4-nitrophenol = 50 mg/L, Ozone flow rate: 100 mL/min, catalyst loading = 0.1 g/L, Temperature: 25 oC.
For a synergistic effect using 30 mg/L ozone dosage together with 0.1g/L PMS loading, both 4-ntirophenol degradation curve and TOC removal rate (Fig. 11(B)) were quite similar to those of 30 mg/L ozone only, suggesting that no synergistic effect occurred. Nevertheless, when PMS loading was increased to 0.5 g/L, under the same ozone dosage, the catalytic reaction rate was improved immensely and complete 4-nitrophenol decomposition was achieved within 45 min. Moreover, the TOC removal rate has been elevated to more than
80%. Both the catalytic reaction rate and TOC removal rate were comparable with those of catalytic ozonation using 50 mg/Lozone dosage. It is suggested that the hydroxyl radicals and sulfate radicals generated by activation of PMS promoted the catalytic ozonation process to produce more active radicals. In the meantime, these hydroxyl/sulfate radicals contributed to 4-nitrophenol degradation and TOC mineralization. When PMS loading rate was further increased to 1 g/L, no improvement in reaction rate and TOC mineralization were observed and the curves almost overlapped. It was proposed that in this scenario, active species seemed to be saturated andsome of them were self-consumed by free radicalreactions. However, the detailed radical generation process including the free radical quenching still remained unclear and further investigation is required.Based on these results, it could be found that synergistic effect reached the optimum when PMS loading is 0.5 g/L. Furthermore, this novel synergistic catalytic ozonationprocess using 30 mg/L ozone dosage could achieve even better result than the traditional catalytic ozonation employing 50 mg/L O3 dosage, enabling the process to be more effective and thus providing a novel and alternative way fororganic pollutant degradation and mineralization.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: 2D γ-MnO2/2D rGOhybrid materials were obtained by a facile hydrothermal method employing rGO, potassium permanganate and hydrochloric acid as precursors. Compared with commercial MnO2, the 2D/2D nanocomposite showed superior capability in catalytic ozonation process for 4-nitrophenol removal.Quenching tests displayed that 4-nitrophenol degradation is dominated by ·O2¯ and 1O2, but not ·OH. Stability tests showed that 2D MnO2/rGO catalysts possessed a good stability even in the third run. And the slight deactivation may be mainly resulted from the transformation of the oxidation state of MnO2. A synergistic effect of catalytic ozonation with PMS for 4-nitrophenol degradation was evaluated, and it was found that the addition of PMS could promote the catalytic ozonation process. This study provided a feasible and alternative approach for removal of organic pollutants.

metadata.abstractText: Two-dimensional reduced graphene oxide (2D rGO) was employed as both a shape-directing medium and support to fabricate 2D γ-MnO2/2D rGOnano-hybrids (MnO2/rGO) via a facile hydrothermal route. For the first time, the 2D/2D hybrid materials were used for catalytic ozonation of 4-nitrophenol. The catalytic efficiency of MnO2/rGO was much higher than either MnO2 or rGO only, andrGO was suggested to play the role for promoting electron transfers. Quenching tests using tert-butanol, p-benzoquinone, and sodium azidesuggested
